Notes: Albania has started by reserving 500 doses for health workers from Kosovo and has also indicated that more doses will follow.
Alrosa, a diamond mining company from Russia with mines in Angola, will buy and donate the vaccine to Angola. Doses not available.
Alrosa, a diamond mining company from Russia, will buy and donate the vaccine to Zimbabwe. Doses not available.
Australia has promised a grant for 28m USD to purchase 3m vaccine doses (unclear which manufacturer).
Australia has donated 8000 doses to PNG and has committed to procuring another 1m doses for PNG that will be paid for by Australia.
Barbados received a vaccine donation from India; no record of other purchase of AZ, so appears that they donated part of this received donation from India to Belize.
Barbados received a vaccine donation from India; Barbados then donated some of those doses to Grenada
Barbados received a vaccine donation from India, then donated some of those doses to Guyana
Barbados received a vaccine donation from India, subsequently donated some doses to St. Lucia
Barbados received a vaccine donation from India, then donated some of those doses to Trinidad and Tobago
Delivery has not yet occurred as of end of April 2021
0.1m doses, along with purchase of 0.103m doses
Another 0.2m doses have been purchased by Botswana.
The first donation of 1m doses arrived in two batches, followed by two more donations of 0.4m and 0.3m respectively.
China also agreed to forgive 13 million USD in public debt at the same time.
Donations received in two batches of 300,000 doses each.
Iraq has separate purchasing agreement for 2m doses. A second batch of donations was sent in April 2021, but the doses are not reported.
A first batch of 0.1m doses has been delivered. There are also some unconfirmed reports that Maldives is purchasing the Sinopharm vaccine (separate from the donation)
China has promised doses but they have not been shipped yet. The vaccine being donated is also not clear
First reported in Feb, the donated vaccines arrived in March and will be used for Nepal's second phase of vaccinations. 0.5m doses have been received but some reports mention a total of 0.8m doses.

Notes: This the first vaccine to reach Niger
Total 1.5m doses donated so far, with another 0.05m doses likely to be donated
Donation was announced in Feb 2021 but is yet to delivered. Delay is reportedly due to pending approvals in PNG
As of April 2021, 0.6m doses already donated, and China has said it will donate 0.4m doses more. The Philippines also has a procurement arrangement with Sinovac
Donation of 0.6m finalised and recieved in April 2021, which was used to vaccinate the Chinese workers in Sri Lanka. Second donation of 0.5m received in late May 2021.
China has offered the vaccine and the T&T govt has accepted it. Delivery is yet to be made
Donation has not been finalized.
Donations sent in two batches of 200,000 doses each
Doses donated by EU, facilitated by Austria
Doses donated by EU, facilitated by Austria

Unwanted doses sent on loan to German border state
Dominica received a vaccine donation from India, then proceeded to donate some of those doses to other countries, including Antigua and Barbuda
Dominica received a vaccine donation from India, then proceeded to donate some of those doses to Grenada.
Dominica received a vaccine donation from India, then donated some of those doses to St. Kitts and Nevis
Dominica received a vaccine donation from India, then donated some of those doses to St. Lucia.
Dominica received a vaccine donation from India, then donated some of those doses to St. Vincent and the Grenadines
France plans to donate 0.5m doses by June 2021; has only specified that 0.1m will be AstraZeneca, rest are unclear. France announced late May 2021 that it would donate 30m doses total to COVAX
France has donated 0.1m doses of AZ. Plans to donate 0.5m doses total from different vaccines
Germany has pledged to donate 30m doses; not clear if this will be donated to COVAX or bilaterally to poor nations
Three separate donations of 2m, 1.2m and 0.1m doses
Initial donation of 0.15m doses, followed by another 0.4m doses in March
US embassy donated locally-sourced cold storage for the vaccines
India has already sent 0.15m of the total promised doses. Reports do not mention donation or purchase but is most likely a donation

2 shipments of 0.1m each. The vaccine shipment is part of India's neighbourhood first foreign policy as 'under grant assistance', and delivered on 20 jan. The govt hopes to ship about 1m doses to Bhutan. This shipment is among the first in the line of countries set to receive vaccine doses from India and also the first in South Asia. This also puts India ahead of China which had also committed to supplying vaccine in the South Asian region. Pakistan is reportedly left out of this vaccine assistance.
HT reported 0.15m doses, but official govt sources report 0.1m, which is used here.

The vaccine shipment is part of India's neighbourhood first foreign policy as 'under grant assistance', and expected to be delivered on 21 jan. This shipment is among the first in the line of countries set to receive vaccine doses from India and also the first in South Asia. This also puts India ahead of China which had also committed to supplying vaccine in the South Asian region. Pakistan is reportedly left out of this vaccine assistance.
Official sources report 0.2m doses, lower than the earlier reported 0.5m doses.
The number of doses has not been reported. A different article in FinancialExpress mentions that almost half a million doses will be donated of AstraZeneca but nothing on donations of Bharat Biotech
Earlier reports state 0.1m doses, but official Indian sources report 0.05m doses.

According to UN Peacekeeping, currently, a total of 94,484 personnel are serving in 12 peacekeeping operations across the world led by the Department of Peace Operations. The donation will allow vaccinations for all the personnel.

Thought to be in response to Czech Republic's promise to open a diplomatic office in Jerusalem. Plans for donation appear to be suspended after Israel came under criticism for sharing doses abroad before vaccinating Palestinians.

Thought to be in response to Guatemala moving its embassy to Jerusalem. Vaccines have arried in Guatemala, but plans for donation to other countries appear to be temporarily suspended after Israel was criticized for sending vaccines abroad before vaccinating Palestinians.

Thought to be in response to Honduras pledging to move its embassy to Jerusalem. Vaccines have been received, but plans for donations to other countries appear to be suspended after Israel was criticized for sending vaccines abroad before sharing with Palestinians.
It has been reported that Israel agreed to purchase an undisclosed number of Gamaleya vaccines in exchange for a prisoner swap in February 2021.

According to the Washington Post, the Palestinian health minister said on 20 Feb that Israel had agreed to providing 0.1m doses for Palestinian workers who regularly cross into Israel to work. Israel has yet to publicly confirm that arrangement. A different Reuters article reported that Israel had confirmed it will allocate 0.13m doses. This is in addition to the 5,000 doses to Palestinians for front-line medical workers. There are an estimated 5m Palestinians living in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank.
Unclear which vaccine(s) will be donated or whether the vaccines will be donated to COVAX or through bilateral donations
Malaysia has approved donation of undisclosed Chinese vaccine to Bosnia

MTN Group has donated 25 million USD to the African Union, to be used to purchase up to 7 million doses of vaccines (it is unclear from which manufacturer, although at least some of them are from AstraZeneca). As of April 2021, nine african countries have received doses - Ghana, Gambia, Liberia, Guinea Bissau, Sierra Leone, Nigeria, Senegal, Mauritius and Togo
New Zealand announced donation at a Gavi event, did not mention which vaccine.

Reports suggest Norway has donated nearly 700,000 doses as of March 2021 and plans to donate up to roughly 2m doses. These doses are the shares that Norway had reserved via COVAX, but it has chosen not to receive them and to have them sent to other countries instead. Given how allocations with COVAX work, it is not clear which vaccines will be donated, but so far it has been AstraZeneca.
Reports suggest Norway will 'lend' these unused doses to Sweden and Iceland
Reports suggest Norway will 'lend' these unused doses to Sweden and Iceland
Little information provided, beyond that Serbia will import doses from Poland.

Portugal has stated it will send 5% of its allocation of vaccines through the EU purchasing arrangement - equivalent to 1.75 million doses - to a group of former Portuguese colonies. It is unclear which vaccine will be donated or how many doses will go to each of the countries.

Portugal has stated it will send 5% of its allocation of vaccines through the EU purchasing arrangement - equivalent to 1.75 million doses - to a group of former Portuguese colonies. It is unclear which vaccine will be donated or how many doses will go to each of the countries.

Romania is donating these doses from its EU allocated doses.
Armenia received 60 doses, and is expecting another 1000 doses as a gift
The ministry announced that it will be getting Sputnik V from the Panama ambassador, but other reports identify it as coming from Russia.
No update after it was first announced in Feb 21
The SearchLight article mentions that vaccines were donated by a "friend" of the country. However, previous reports have indicated some donation from Russia
Reports say Serbia donated 10,000 doses to Federation entity.

Media reports suggest that Serbia sent vaccines to Serb-dominated regions in Kosovo without the Kosovo govt approval. There are reports that Serbia is also willing to make further donations to Kosovo, even in non-Serb majority areas.
Unclear whether this is a donation or a purchase. Earlier reports identified is as a purchase, but more recent reports categorize it as a donation.

South Africa announced this after a small trial found that the vaccine was not effective against the local variant. Although SA bought 1.5m doses and has paused distribution, it did not explicitly mention if all the doses will be redirected to AU and whether they were be bought or donated. AU GNI/population calculated without Saharawi due to lack of World Bank data.

South Africa sold its AZ doses to other AU states after a small trial found that the vaccine was not effective against the local variant. SA had already received 1m doses with an additional 0.5m pending to be delivered. 9 AU states have received the doses in the first round, with another 5 states receiving doses in the next round. No mention of the doses, prices or the countries receiving them. AU GNI/population calculated without Saharawi due to lack of World Bank data.
Andorra will reportedly pay the same price that Spain paid for these doses
According to this arrangement, Andorra will pay the same price that Spain for the vaccines.
Spain has stated that it will donate at least 7.5m doses of the vaccines it receives through its EU allocation to Latin American countries via COVAX
Donation made to northern Cyprus [the area recognized solely by Turkey as the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus].
Albania received a donation from an undisclosed EU country.
The Netherlands is reported to have purchased, from one or more EU countries, an additional 600,000 doses
Malaysia declined the offer from the UAE, stating that Sinopharm needed to be approved by their regulatory first.

Unclear if vaccinations will be approved by the Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, as the donation has been secured by his political rival Mohammad Dahlan. Also unclear if Israel would allow transfer of doses from Gaza to West Bank.
The White House has stated that the vaccines would be a loan - vaccines would be shipped now in exchange for doses sent back to the US at a later date.

The White House has stated that the vaccines would be a loan - vaccines would be shipped now in exchange for doses sent back to the US at a later date. The donation/loan appears to be linked to ongoing negotiations over the flow of migrants at the US-Mexico border.

The US and South Korea announced a donation of vaccines sufficient to vaccinate 550,000 South Korean military members. Vaccine brand not specified; assuming earlier report of donating 13,000 doses of J&J is part of this arrangement and the vaccine being donated is a two-dose vaccine, that amounts to 1.074m doses donated.
The US military has reportedly offered doses of the vaccine to the South Korean military, but it's not clear if this would be a donation.
The US announced it will send doses purchased for domestic supply of Moderna, Pfizer/BioNTech, and/or Johnson & Johnson abroad. Donations expected to begin in June 2021.

The US has stated that it will donate up to 60m doses of AstraZeneca vaccines, pending safety clearance by the FDA in the coming weeks. It has not yet stated to which countries these vaccines will be donated, although there is supposition that some will go to India, which is facing a large second wave.
